channel.title: California
channel.description: California news and features from the Los Angeles Times.

item.title: O.C. health officer receives threats over face covering mandate
item.dc:creator: Hannah Fry, Colleen Shalby
item.description: Orange County Board of Supervisors Chair Michelle Steel condemned what she deemed to be a death threat against County Health Officer Dr. Nichole Quick this week.
item.content:encoded: Orange County Board of Supervisors Chair Michelle Steel condemned what she deemed to be a death threat against County Health Officer Dr. Nichole Quick this week.

media:content.media:description: GRASS VALLEY, MAY 21, 2020: Dawn Krawczyk, a sales floor manager at Yuba Blue, a women's clothing store in Grass Valley, uses steam to disinfect a romper, before placing it back on the rack. The store recently re-opened after being forced to close due to the coronavirus outbreak. (Mel Melcon/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Protesters clash with police, shut down 110 Freeway, in downtown L.A.; 2 LAPD officers injured
item.dc:creator: Andrew J. Campa, Monte Morin, Ruben Vives
item.description: The crowd mostly dressed in black held signs and rode bicycles across traffic lanes while some held up sign that read "We are not thugs."
item.content:encoded: The crowd mostly dressed in black held signs and rode bicycles across traffic lanes while some held up sign that read "We are not thugs."

media:content.media:description: California Highway Patrol officers protect themselves from protesters on the northbound 110 Freeway in downtown Los Angeles on Friday.

item.title: How should L.A. be redesigned for coronavirus? Are doorknobs out? We asked the experts
item.dc:creator: Carolina A. Miranda
item.description: COVID-19 has Thom Mayne, Michael Maltzan, Barbara Bestor, Rachel Allen and more Los Angeles architects rethinking design, from balconies to doorknobs.
item.content:encoded: COVID-19 has Thom Mayne, Michael Maltzan, Barbara Bestor, Rachel Allen and more Los Angeles architects rethinking design, from balconies to doorknobs.

item.title: California police unions condemn actions of Minnesota officer in George Floyd's death
item.dc:creator: Anita Chabria
item.description: Rank and file police in California Thursday said they condemn the actions of Minnesota officers involved in the death of George Floyd.
item.content:encoded: Rank and file police in California Thursday said they condemn the actions of Minnesota officers involved in the death of George Floyd.

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles, CA, Thursday, May 28, 2020 - Dozens of protestors, many with the Black Lives Matters movement, stand off with police in response to the death of George Floyd. (Robert Gauthier / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Bullet train would nick jobs, homes and parks on 14-mile route from L.A. to Burbank
item.dc:creator: Ralph Vartabedian
item.description: California's future high-speed rail line from Burbank to Los Angeles would follow an existing 14-mile rail corridor but run through dozens of businesses, a draft environmental study found.
item.content:encoded: California's future high-speed rail line from Burbank to Los Angeles would follow an existing 14-mile rail corridor but run through dozens of businesses, a draft environmental study found.

media:content.media:description: A Southwest airplane takes off over the tower at Bob Hope Airport in Burbank on March 24.

item.title: San Diego to allow sunbathing, other passive beach activities
item.dc:creator: Lyndsay Winkley
item.description: The new regulations allow people in the same household to sit together on the sand. Activities like football and volleyball are still banned, and parking lots and piers remain closed.
item.content:encoded: The new regulations allow people in the same household to sit together on the sand. Activities like football and volleyball are still banned, and parking lots and piers remain closed.

media:content.media:description: SDPD at Ocean Beach used all-terrain vehicles to help inform and enforce county beach orders for "No Stopping No Sitting."
media:content.media:credit: Nelvin C. Cepeda/Nelvin C. Cepeda/The San Diego Union-Tribune

item.title: Ventura County to extend stay-at-home order while continuing to ease restrictions
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby
item.description: The Ventura County directive, put in place to stem the coronavirus' spread, is set to expire Sunday. Health officials plan to extend it, but with further relaxations.
item.content:encoded: The Ventura County directive, put in place to stem the coronavirus' spread, is set to expire Sunday. Health officials plan to extend it, but with further relaxations.

media:content.media:description: VENTURA, CA -- MAY 28: Mary Jasso-Brooks, of Ventura, with James, left, and Paige, walk along the surf at the beach on Thursday, May 28, 2020, in Ventura, CA. While many parks and beaches in Ventura County have been open for active use for weeks, Ventura city officials will begin to further ease restrictions at their outdoor spaces starting Friday. "Passive" activities such as sitting and sunbathing will be allowed "as long as the public maintains a safe physical distance of six feet and avoids congregating in large groups. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Column: The words of Lincoln, Truman and Reagan got us through crises. Trump's words makes everything worse
item.dc:creator: Steve Lopez
item.description: FDR said, "repetition does not transform a lie into a truth." Trump has to hope that's not true.
item.content:encoded: FDR said, "repetition does not transform a lie into a truth." Trump has to hope that's not true.

media:content.media:description: Clockwise from top left; Painting of Gen. George Washington leads in the battle at Princeton, Jan. 3, 1777; an oil painting of Thomas Jefferson in 1805; 1865 photo of President Abraham Lincoln in Washington; President Donald Trump in the Oval Office; 1961 photo of President John F. Kennedy; and 1916 photo of President Woodrow Wilson throwing out ball at a baseball game in Washington.

item.title: Will small-business owners go to jail for breaking coronavirus rules? We'll find out
item.dc:creator: Margot Roosevelt
item.description: L.A. is prosecuting more than 70 businesses so far for allegedly flouting COVID-19 rules. The group includes pet groomers, salons and smoke shops.
item.content:encoded: L.A. is prosecuting more than 70 businesses so far for allegedly flouting COVID-19 rules. The group includes pet groomers, salons and smoke shops.

media:content.media:description: SHERMAN OAKS, CA-MAY 15, 2020: Janet Tavakoli, 69, owner of Sherman Oaks Beauty Collection, wearing a protective mask against the coronavirus, is photographed next to bottles of hand sanitizer, right, for sale inside her store. The store is one of 60 non-essential businesses cited by Los Angeles City Attorney Mike Feuer for "flouting the city's Safer at Home order. Tavakoli says she shut down her store for 2 weeks, losing $15,000 in sales but reopened after seeing beauty store competitors open. (Mel Melcon/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Bald eagles return to nest in Orange County neighborhood
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby
item.description: For the last three years, two bald eagles have been returning to nest in the backyard of a north O.C. home.
item.content:encoded: For the last three years, two bald eagles have been returning to nest in the backyard of a north O.C. home.

media:content.media:description: NORTH ORANGE COUNTY, CA - MAY 27: A tagged female of two parent bald eagles takes flight from a branch high in a tree not far from its nest in north Orange County containing two juvenile eagles Wednesday, May 27, 2020. The blue $85 tag indicates it is part of the Institute for Wildlife Studies project to rebuild the bald eagle population on the Channel Islands, was hatched in 2013 at Santa Rosa Island and given the name La'i. Neighbors say it's the third year the bald eagles have returned to the area to raise chicks. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times) (Please note: Do not to disclose the location of the nest so the bald eagles would not be disturbed.)
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben/Allen J. Schaben/Los Angeles Times

item.title: L.A. County can reopen restaurants, barbershops, salons, Newsom says
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth, Ronald D. White, Andrea Chang, Jaclyn Cosgrove
item.description: L.A. County, the epicenter of California's coronavirus outbreak, can reopen restaurants for in-person dining and resume services at hairstyling shops.
item.content:encoded: L.A. County, the epicenter of California's coronavirus outbreak, can reopen restaurants for in-person dining and resume services at hairstyling shops.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MARCH 18, 2020 Grace Curran, restaurant manager wipes table tops with disinfectant at Republique (French Restaurant) located at 624 South La Brea as the restaurant continues to serve patrons who love the fine pastries in the morning with a full menu available for carry-out and delivery on Wednesday morning as the restaurant has changed its work flow to accommodate for the coronavirus limitations. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Sonoma County retreated on reopening. Now the sheriff will stop enforcing coronavirus orders
item.dc:creator: Hannah Fry
item.description: Sheriff Mark Essick says his department will stop enforcing local shelter-in-place restrictions amid the coronavirus pandemic, even as cases rise.
item.content:encoded: Sheriff Mark Essick says his department will stop enforcing local shelter-in-place restrictions amid the coronavirus pandemic, even as cases rise.

media:content.media:description: In this photo taken Wednesday, April 1, 2020, are the empty grounds of the historic Buena Vista Winery in Sonoma, Calif. Wineries that want to stay viable and connected to their customers during the coronavirus pandemic are harnessing platforms such as Facebook Live to offer virtual wine experiences. Tasting rooms in California shut down last month after the governor ordered businesses to close to slow the spread of the new virus. (AP Photo/Eric Risberg)

item.title: Offer of masks for California drew a cast of characters, from a lobbyist to an ex-con
item.dc:creator: Adam Elmahrek, Melody Gutierrez
item.description: A deal that never materialized to sell tens of millions of masks to the state government offers a rare behind-the-scenes view into the masks trade.
item.content:encoded: A deal that never materialized to sell tens of millions of masks to the state government offers a rare behind-the-scenes view into the masks trade.

media:content.media:description: Some health care experts recommend the use of N95 respirator masks to help protect against wildfire smoke. Simple dust or surgical masks do not offer the same kind of protection, they warn. (Ana B. Ibarra/California Healthline)

item.title: Border Patrol arrests convicted murderer smuggled into U.S. in Imperial County
item.dc:creator: Kristi Sturgill
item.description: El Centro Border Patrol arrested a 39-year-old convicted murder Wednesday after the vehicle he was in attempted to avoid an immigration checkpoint.
item.content:encoded: El Centro Border Patrol arrested a 39-year-old convicted murder Wednesday after the vehicle he was in attempted to avoid an immigration checkpoint.

media:content.media:description: A Border Patrol agent drives near the U.S.-Mexico border fence in Santa Teresa, N.M.

item.title: Fontana protest over George Floyd's death ends in 9 arrests, police say
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: Protesters blocked traffic and threw rocks at businesses and passing cars, authorities said, damaging windows at Fontana City Hall.
item.content:encoded: Protesters blocked traffic and threw rocks at businesses and passing cars, authorities said, damaging windows at Fontana City Hall.

item.title: Whites far less likely to die from the coronavirus than blacks, Latinos in L.A. County
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II
item.description: The death rate in Los Angeles County is far greater for Native Hawaiian/Pacific Islander, black and Latino residents than for white people, data show.
item.content:encoded: The death rate in Los Angeles County is far greater for Native Hawaiian/Pacific Islander, black and Latino residents than for white people, data show.

media:content.media:description: INGLEWOOD-CA-APRIL 15, 2020: Clarice Kavanaugh places a hand on her friend Charles Jackson's casket at Inglewood Park Cemetery in Inglewood on Wednesday, April 15, 2020. Jackson was diagnosed with covid-19 after returning home from a black ski trip in Idaho, and died days later in the hospital. (Christina House / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California surpasses 4,000 coronavirus deaths, with L.A. County hardest hit
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby, Luke Money, Maura Dolan, Jaclyn Cosgrove
item.description: Los Angeles County recorded 50 new deaths Friday, a number that pushed the overall death toll in California past 4,000.
item.content:encoded: Los Angeles County recorded 50 new deaths Friday, a number that pushed the overall death toll in California past 4,000.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA-MAY 28, 2020: Pedestrians cross the street at the intersection of 6th St. and Broadway in downtown Los Angeles. (Mel Melcon/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Reopening California off to a slow start as customers stay away, fears of coronavirus still loom large
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Lai, Andrew J. Campa, Maria L. La Ganga, Doug Smith
item.description: The gradual reopening underscores the difficult choice facing retailers, employees and consumers alike: If stores are full, the pandemic could worsen. If they're empty, there goes the economy.
item.content:encoded: The gradual reopening underscores the difficult choice facing retailers, employees and consumers alike: If stores are full, the pandemic could worsen. If they're empty, there goes the economy.

media:content.media:description: GLENDALE, CA - MAY 28: Wearing masks/face covering and practicing social distancing, people wander the Glendale Galleria on Thursday, May 28, 2020 in Glendale, CA. The Glendale Galleria which has been shuttered to help fight the spread of the novel coronavirus, COVID19, was open today as a result of Gov. Gavin Newsom's easing of requirements for reopening businesses. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Chinese billionaire helped L.A. councilman settle sexual harassment suit, feds say
item.dc:creator: David Zahniser, Emily Alpert Reyes
item.description: Court documents in the George Esparza case allege that a billionaire Chinese real estate developer played a crucial role in helping L.A. Councilman Jose Huizar settle a sexual harassment lawsuit as he was seeking re-election.
item.content:encoded: Court documents in the George Esparza case allege that a billionaire Chinese real estate developer played a crucial role in helping L.A. Councilman Jose Huizar settle a sexual harassment lawsuit as he was seeking re-election.

media:content.media:description: A Feb. 15, 2012, photo of Los Angeles City Councilman Jose Huizar and a Jan. 8, 2010, image of his then-deputy chief of staff, Francine Godoy. Huizar has denied allegations in a complaint against him by Godoy.

item.title: Supreme Court rejects challenge to California limits on church crowds during pandemic
item.dc:creator: David G. Savage
item.description: Supreme Court rules in a case in which a San Diego-area church challenged Gov. Gavin Newsom's order limiting attendance because of the coronavirus.
item.content:encoded: Supreme Court rules in a case in which a San Diego-area church challenged Gov. Gavin Newsom's order limiting attendance because of the coronavirus.

media:content.media:description: The U.S. Supreme Court building in Washington.

item.title: California's coronavirus budget crisis leaves Newsom and lawmakers at odds
item.dc:creator: John Myers
item.description: The alternative budget adopted by Senate Democrats differs from the governor's proposal to address the state's coronavirus fueled deficit in several key ways.
item.content:encoded: The alternative budget adopted by Senate Democrats differs from the governor's proposal to address the state's coronavirus fueled deficit in several key ways.

item.title: Los Angeles County public defender dies from COVID-19
item.dc:creator: Matt Hamilton
item.description: It marked the first coronavirus death in the ranks of the L.A. County public defender's office, and it comes as courts across California chart a path to reopen services and ease restrictions.
item.content:encoded: It marked the first coronavirus death in the ranks of the L.A. County public defender's office, and it comes as courts across California chart a path to reopen services and ease restrictions.

item.title: Protesters return to downtown Los Angeles to decry police killing in Minneapolis
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth
item.description: The demonstration, organized by the Los Angeles chapter of Black Lives Matter, was on a smaller scale than the day before.
item.content:encoded: The demonstration, organized by the Los Angeles chapter of Black Lives Matter, was on a smaller scale than the day before.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MAY 28, 2020: A protester tosses a bottled water on a CHP vehicle as other Black Lives Matter protesters swarm the car in a rally in front of LAPD headquarters to protest the death of George Floyd during the coronavirus pandemic on May 28, 2020 in Los Angeles, California. (Gina Ferazzi / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: More than 60 Imperial County coronavirus patients are being treated at Riverside County hospitals
item.dc:creator: Kailyn Brown
item.description: More than 60 Imperial County coronavirus patients are being treated in Riverside County due to a hospital surge.
item.content:encoded: More than 60 Imperial County coronavirus patients are being treated in Riverside County due to a hospital surge.

media:content.media:description: RIVERSIDE, CA- APRIL 8, 2020: Medical staff carry a patient's belongings as she is evacuated from Magnolia Rehabilitation and Nursing Center after 39 tested positive for coronavirus and the nursing staff was not showing up to work for their own safety on April 8, 2020 in Riverside, California. All 84 resident patients will be removed to other facilities.(Gina Ferazzi / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: L.A. County officials hope reopening plan is approved by Friday
item.dc:creator: Jaclyn Cosgrove, Colleen Shalby
item.description: Los Angeles County officials are hoping to find out as early as Friday whether they'll be allowed to reopen restaurants for in-person dining, along with barbershops and hair salons.
item.content:encoded: Los Angeles County officials are hoping to find out as early as Friday whether they'll be allowed to reopen restaurants for in-person dining, along with barbershops and hair salons.

media:content.media:description: GLENDALE, CA - MAY 28: Signs that say Dick's Sporting Goods is open are seen as people wearing masks/face covering and practicing social distancing wander the Glendale Galleria on Thursday, May 28, 2020 in Glendale, CA. The Glendale Galleria which has been shuttered to help fight the spread of the novel coronavirus, COVID19, was open today as a result of Gov. Gavin Newsom's easing of requirements for reopening businesses. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Garcetti, Martinez call on L.A. City Councilman Huizar to resign
item.dc:creator: Dakota Smith
item.description: L.A. Mayor Eric Garcetti and City Council President Nury Martinez called on Councilman Jose Huizar to resign amid an ongoing federal investigation into a City Hall "pay-to-play" scandal. Huizar has not been charged.
item.content:encoded: L.A. Mayor Eric Garcetti and City Council President Nury Martinez called on Councilman Jose Huizar to resign amid an ongoing federal investigation into a City Hall "pay-to-play" scandal. Huizar has not been charged.

media:content.media:description: 14th District council member Jose Huizar.Â

item.title: Yolo County ditches its local shelter in place order, but state order remains
item.dc:creator: Cindy Carcamo
item.description: Yolo County has lifted its local coronavirus shelter in place order, but the state order remains in effect
item.content:encoded: Yolo County has lifted its local coronavirus shelter in place order, but the state order remains in effect

media:content.media:description: This transmission electron microscope image shows SARS-CoV-2, also known as 2019-nCoV, the coronavirus virus that causes COVID-19
media:content.media:credit: (National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases Rocky Mountain Laboratories)

item.title: San Clemente removes controversial beach fencing amid pressure from county sheriff
item.dc:creator: Hannah Fry
item.description: Access will be a little easier for beachgoers visiting San Clemente this week after city leaders voted to reopen parking lots and remove fencing that prompted community outcry and a stern rebuke from the county's top law enforcement official.
item.content:encoded: Access will be a little easier for beachgoers visiting San Clemente this week after city leaders voted to reopen parking lots and remove fencing that prompted community outcry and a stern rebuke from the county's top law enforcement official.

media:content.media:description: SAN CLEMENTE, CA - MAY 18: Families practice social distancing while playing in the water and sand near the San Clemente Pier on Monday, May 18, 2020 in San Clemente, CA. Orange County beaches are currently open for active recreation, which includes swimming, surfing, and running. (Gabriella Angotti-Jones / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Travel ban lifted in El Dorado County but Lake Tahoe tourism still prohibited
item.dc:creator: Cindy Carcamo
item.description: El Dorado County lifted its nonessential travel ban Wednesday but state officials will keep Lake Tahoe off limits
item.content:encoded: El Dorado County lifted its nonessential travel ban Wednesday but state officials will keep Lake Tahoe off limits

media:content.media:description: A report released this week finds that Lake Tahoe's water clarity declined slightly last year, but the overall trend remains positive.
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times

item.title: Synagogues in L.A. can reopen, but many rabbis are holding off
item.dc:creator: Leila Miller
item.description: Synagogues in L.A. are now allowed to reopen, but rabbis have been grappling with the right thing to do.
item.content:encoded: Synagogues in L.A. are now allowed to reopen, but rabbis have been grappling with the right thing to do.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA-MAY 28, 2020: Even though Young Israel of Century City synagogue on Pico Blvd. in Los Angeles has permission from the city and county of Los Angeles to reopen in a limited fashion, it's rabbi has firmly decided to hold off. Rabbi Elazar Muskin is among a group of local Orthodox rabbis who have signed a letter stating they will wait at least two weeks to see whether coronavirus cases surge upwards. (Mel Melcon/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: San Francisco to allow outdoor dining, exercise classes and spectator-free sports in coming weeks
item.dc:creator: Maura Dolan
item.description: San Francisco will allow outdoor dining, exercise classes and spectator-free sports in the coming weeks.
item.content:encoded: San Francisco will allow outdoor dining, exercise classes and spectator-free sports in the coming weeks.

media:content.media:description: SAN FRANCISCO: The Golden State Warriors are in Oakland, but those in the know stay in S.F. Pictured: Evening commuters make their way across the Bay Bridge as a storm passes behind the San Francisco skyline as seen from Yerba Buena Island.

item.title: L.A. shopping malls reopen. The feel is more ghost town than Black Friday
item.dc:creator: Doug Stevens , Stephanie Lai
item.description: Many retailers and malls were allowed to reopen their doors this week, but customers so far have been slow to return. And many stores remained closed as well.
item.content:encoded: Many retailers and malls were allowed to reopen their doors this week, but customers so far have been slow to return. And many stores remained closed as well.

The Glendale Galleria which has been shuttered to help fight the spread of the novel coronavirus, COVID19, was open today as a result of Gov. Gavin Newsom's easing of requirements for reopening businesses. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: No pay cuts for California elected officials amid budget crisis prompted by coronavirus
item.dc:creator: Patrick McGreevy
item.description: The decision came with an entreaty from Tom Dalzell, the chairman of the state Citizens Compensation Commission, who called on California's 132 elected state officials to each consider taking less pay during the coronavirus crisis.
item.content:encoded: The decision came with an entreaty from Tom Dalzell, the chairman of the state Citizens Compensation Commission, who called on California's 132 elected state officials to each consider taking less pay during the coronavirus crisis.

media:content.media:description: Members of the state Assembly, seen here on the first day of session in Sacramento on Dec. 5, 2016, will be able to collectively introduce an additional 800 proposed laws this session under looser organizational rules.

item.title: A-OK boomers: New 'Laurel Canyon' doc will make you swoon over the scene all over again
item.dc:creator: Randall Roberts
item.description: "Laurel Canyon," the new two-part documentary on Epix premiering Sunday, is the most comprehensive and musically satisfying document of a notably insular scene
item.content:encoded: "Laurel Canyon," the new two-part documentary on Epix premiering Sunday, is the most comprehensive and musically satisfying document of a notably insular scene

media:content.media:description: Joni Mitchell in a scene from the documentary "Laurel Canyon." Credit: Henry Diltz

item.title: Inmate labeled as 'recovered' from coronavirus dies at Terminal Island
item.dc:creator: Richard Winton
item.description: The prisoner, the ninth to die at the San Pedro facility, tested positive for the virus in mid-April and was hospitalized a month later after symptoms returned.
item.content:encoded: The prisoner, the ninth to die at the San Pedro facility, tested positive for the virus in mid-April and was hospitalized a month later after symptoms returned.

media:content.media:description: SAN PEDRO CA. APRIL 29, 2020 -- Exterior view of the Federal Correctional Institution Terminal Island in San Pedro. Nearly half of the inmates at the federal prison at Terminal Island in San Pedro have tested positive for the coronavirus in what had has become the nation's worst outbreak in a federal penitentiary. As of Tuesday, 443 of the prison's 1,055 inmates have the virus, along with 10 staff members. Two inmates have already died of complications related to COVID-19, according to the Bureau of Prisons. (Christina House / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California's top court limits what government may charge for public records
item.dc:creator: Maura Dolan
item.description: Government agencies in California may not charge for redacting documents sought in public records requests, the California Supreme Court rules.
item.content:encoded: Government agencies in California may not charge for redacting documents sought in public records requests, the California Supreme Court rules.

media:content.media:description: Justice Leondra Kruger working and poses for a portrait in her downtown office, was appointed by Jerry Brown to the California Supreme Court. She votes more conservatively than the other two Brown appointees because she prefers the law to develop very slowly. (David Butow / For The Times)

item.title: Earthquake: 3.5 quake near Soledad, Calif.

item.content:encoded: A magnitude 3.5 earthquake was reported Thursday at 12:19 p.m. Pacific time 11 miles from Soledad, Calif., according to the USGS.

item.content:encoded: The police dog was taken to a veterinary hospital and underwent emergency surgery. He is expected to make a full recovery.

Tasting rooms in California shut down last month after the governor ordered businesses to close to slow the spread of the new virus. (AP Photo/Eric Risberg)

(Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: L.A. County reports 48 more coronavirus deaths, pushing California's toll to almost 4,000
item.dc:creator: Luke Money, Hannah Fry, Phil Willon
item.description: While much of California is steadily lifting restrictions, two Northern California counties have had to roll back plans as coronavirus infections jumped.
item.content:encoded: While much of California is steadily lifting restrictions, two Northern California counties have had to roll back plans as coronavirus infections jumped.

media:content.media:description: TEMECULA, CA - MAY 26: Gene Kelley, right, co-owner of Skyline Barber Shop cuts Dan Collins, left, hair on Tuesday, May 26, 2020 in Temecula, CA. Gov. Gavin Newsom says California counties that have been granted regional variances allowing more types of businesses to reopen can now permit the reopening of barbershops and hair salons, with modifications such asâ¨protective gear and face coverings during the coronavirus pandemic. (Francine Orr / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Families call for shutdown of Vallejo nursing home with 102 COVID infections, 13 deaths
item.dc:creator: Hayley Smith
item.description: Nearly a quarter of all COVID-19 cases in Solano County, Calif., can be linked to one nursing home in Vallejo. Families want the facility shut down.
item.content:encoded: Nearly a quarter of all COVID-19 cases in Solano County, Calif., can be linked to one nursing home in Vallejo. Families want the facility shut down.

media:content.media:description: A sign is displayed near the entrance of the Windsor Vallejo Care Center on Tuesday, May 5, 2020, in Vallejo, Calif. Numerous residents and staff members at the center have tested positive for coronavirus. (AP Photo/Ben Margot)

item.title: How to search for and find a new rental during coronavirus
item.dc:creator: Jack Harris
item.description: Finding a rental in L.A. was hard enough before the global pandemic. Here's a guide to how to search and move in Southern California, and stay safe.
item.content:encoded: Finding a rental in L.A. was hard enough before the global pandemic. Here's a guide to how to search and move in Southern California, and stay safe.

media:content.media:description: A large apartment is advertised for rent at the corner of California Boulevard and Oakland Avenue on October for 7, 2019 in Pasadena, California. Landlords say state rent caps may force them to raise rents more frequently.(Gina Ferazzi/Los AngelesTimes)

item.title: 700 Chino inmates to be transferred as coronavirus sweeps prison
item.dc:creator: Richard Winton
item.description: The prisoners have tested negative but have histories that make them vulnerable in a facility where the coronavirus has infected every dormitory.
item.content:encoded: The prisoners have tested negative but have histories that make them vulnerable in a facility where the coronavirus has infected every dormitory.

media:content.media:description: Housing in the Elm dorm at California Institution for Men in Chino.

item.title: Record crowds trash Ventura County waterfall with litter, human waste
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: Paradise Falls in Wildwood Regional Park in northwestern Thousand Oaks will remain closed until further notice, conservation agency says.
item.content:encoded: Paradise Falls in Wildwood Regional Park in northwestern Thousand Oaks will remain closed until further notice, conservation agency says.

media:content.media:description: SANTA BARBARA, CA - MAY 28: Brazilian students studying in San Diego dive and swim in the water under Paradise Falls in Thousand Oaks' Wildwood Regional Park on Thursday May 28, 2020 as COSCA announced they will be closing the Falls to the pubic indefinitely after the scenic spot was overrun with crowds, trash and human waste. The Conejo Valley Open Space Conservation Agency announced the closure after a weekend that had rangers trying to keep up with collecting trash left behind by visitors as Ventura County begins to ease restrictions due to Coronavirus and Covid-19 . Cachuma Lake on Thursday, May 28, 2020 in Santa Barbara, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Sunbathing, lounging now allowed at Ventura County beaches
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: The county's decision to permit passive use follows similar action in the coastal cities of Ventura, Oxnard and Port Hueneme.
item.content:encoded: The county's decision to permit passive use follows similar action in the coastal cities of Ventura, Oxnard and Port Hueneme.

media:content.media:description: VENTURA, CA -- MAY 28: Mary Jasso-Brooks, of Ventura, with James, left, and Paige, walk along the surf at the beach on Thursday, May 28, 2020, in Ventura, CA. While many parks and beaches in Ventura County have been open for active use for weeks, Ventura city officials will begin to further ease restrictions at their outdoor spaces starting Friday. "Passive" activities such as sitting and sunbathing will be allowed "as long as the public maintains a safe physical distance of six feet and avoids congregating in large groups. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Photos: Huge L.A. crowds protest George Floyd's death, blocking the 101
item.dc:creator: Times Staff
item.description: These 13 photos show protests in downtown Los Angeles after the Minneapolis man was killed by police.
item.content:encoded: These 13 photos show protests in downtown Los Angeles after the Minneapolis man was killed by police.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MAY 27: Two people stand on a police vehicle during a Black Lives Matter protest in downtown on Wednesday, May 27, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Dania Maxwell / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Reopening California could easily backfire into second wave without masks and distancing, officials warn
item.dc:creator: Hannah Fry, Rong-Gong Lin II, Cindy Chang
item.description: Health officials have stressed that with the easing of stay-at-home orders comes the potential to further spread the coronavirus.
item.content:encoded: Health officials have stressed that with the easing of stay-at-home orders comes the potential to further spread the coronavirus.

media:content.media:description: BOYLE HEIGHTS, CA-MAY 27, 2020: Daniela Prieto, 21, an employee at Deportes Prieto, a retail business on 1st St. in Boyle Heights, disinfects inside the store that is currently only allowing customers to pre-order merchandise and pick up at the store. The business re-opened on Monday with curbside pick-up only after previously being closed due to the coronavirus. (Mel Melcon/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: 'I had to do something': Black barbers and stylists go underground as L.A. salons stay shut
item.dc:creator: Angel Jennings
item.description: In black communities, where barbershops and salons are cultural institutions and gathering places, the lockdown has hit barbers and stylists hard.
item.content:encoded: In black communities, where barbershops and salons are cultural institutions and gathering places, the lockdown has hit barbers and stylists hard.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MAY 16: Unable to open their Mid-City Salon, hair stylists Tia Rose of North Hollywood and Christina Rose of West Covina styles a clients hair in an AirBnb in order to earn a living during the coronavirus pandemic on Saturday, May 16, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. Salons across Los Angeles have been classified as nonessential businesses forcing some hairstylist to take their business underground. (Jason Armond / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Vandalism during heated L.A. protest over George Floyd death sparks concern from police
item.dc:creator: Richard Winton, Matthew Ormseth
item.description: Demonstrators blocked the 101 Freeway, vandalized two CHP cruisers and spray-painted graffiti on LAPD headquarters.
item.content:encoded: Demonstrators blocked the 101 Freeway, vandalized two CHP cruisers and spray-painted graffiti on LAPD headquarters.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MAY 27: Protesters surround a police vehicle on the 101 freeway near downtown Los Angeles on Wednesday, May 27, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. A protester smashed the back window with a skateboard. (Gabriella Angotti-Jones / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Coronavirus ravages poorer L.A. communities while slowing in wealthier ones, data show
item.dc:creator: Tony Barboza, Ben Poston, Ryan Menezes
item.description: Since April 17, coronavirus infection rates have surged in L.A. County's poorer neighborhoods, while cases have risen far more slowly in richer areas.
item.content:encoded: Since April 17, coronavirus infection rates have surged in L.A. County's poorer neighborhoods, while cases have risen far more slowly in richer areas.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MAY 18: Maria Banderas, left, answers questions from medical assistant Dolores Becerra before entering the room where she will receive the oral swab test for coronavirus during walk-in coronavirus testing at St. John's Well Child and Family Center in South Los Angeles, one of the South and Central LA neighborhoods hit hard by the coronavirus Covid-19. South Central on Monday, May 18, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California reopening speeds up even as state hits 100,000 confirmed coronavirus cases

A sign taped to a lightpost tells customers about curbside pickup services at a store in the Santa Anita Mall in Arcadia on Wednesday, May 27, 2020. Stores remained mostly closed despite restrictions being lifted for for in-store shopping throughout California. (Luis Sinco/Los Angeles Times)

item.content:encoded: Assemblyman William Brough (R-Dana Point) was removed from all committee assignments after a state investigation found he made inappropriate comments and engaged in unwanted touching with a woman who complained to the Legislature.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA -- APRIL 21: Francisco Lorenzo prays in front of the closed doors of the Immaculate Conception Catholic Church in downtown on Tuesday, April 21, 2020, in Los Angeles, CA. The Archdiocese of Los Angeles has announced the suspension of public Masses, at least until March 29. "I deeply regret that we are forced to temporarily suspend public celebration of the Mass in the Archdiocese of Los Angeles," Archbishop Jose H. Gomez said in a statement released March 16. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times)

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MAY 27: Hikers enter Runyon Canyon Park at the North entrance on Mulholland Drive in the Hollywood hills on Wednesday morning as the popular park has been reopened and is closely monitored by L.A. City person new under COVID-19 safety guidelines. Visitors are still required to wear masks at the park and people are instructed to walk in lanes with directional arrows trying to maximize social distancing. Hollywood on Wednesday, May 27, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Here is what can now reopen in L.A. County, and here is what is still closed

item.content:encoded: Malls? Movie theaters? Hair salons? Here's a look at which L.A. County businesses can now open and which ones are still closed.

media:content.media:description: BREA, CA - MAY 26: Shoppers walk around the Brea Mall, which reopened Tuesday, where some of the mall's stores opened their doors to shoppers as the state emerges from shutdown orders enacted to slow the spread of the coronavirus. In new guidelines released yesterday ... the re-opening of retail stores for socially distanced shopping experiences remains subject to approval from officials in each of the state's counties. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben/Allen J. Schaben/Los Angeles Times

media:content.media:description: SOUTH LOS ANGELES, MAY 26, 2020 - An investigation is underway after five people were hospitalized following a shooting Tuesday night outside a South Los Angeles apartment complex. The L.A. County Fire Department said the shooting was reported near the intersection of 119th Street and Berendo Avenue in the neighborhood of Athens at about 10:40 p.m. None of the injuries are considered life-threatening

Debra Duardo tours Cerritos Elementary School in Glendale on Tuesday May 26, 2020 considering that with a persisting coronavirus threat, K-12 campuses will try to reopen in the fall. New L.A. County guidelines offer a possible roadmap but it could get complicated and costly to confront the logistics of reopening at an actual school in the wake of Covid-19. item.title: 'Powder keg' at Chuckawalla Valley State Prison with 110 cases of COVID-19 in two weeks
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth
item.description: Until May 13, none of the 2,306 men incarcerated at Chuckawalla Valley State Prison had tested positive for COVID-19, the disease caused by the novel coronavirus. More than 100 inmates have been infected since.
item.content:encoded: Until May 13, none of the 2,306 men incarcerated at Chuckawalla Valley State Prison had tested positive for COVID-19, the disease caused by the novel coronavirus. More than 100 inmates have been infected since.

media:content.media:description: Schaben, Allen J. ÂÂ Â CHINO: AUG. 10, 2009: As viewed through the afternoon heat waves, a corrections officer looks out from a tower over barbed wire fences and transport busses at the California Institution For Men State Prison in Chino. California prisons remain on lockdown after Saturday's riot in Chino. On Aug. 8 a violent riot broke out at the California Institution of Men in the West reception facility. About 200 inmates were injured and 30 remain hospitalized with nonÂlife threatening injuries. Some say the riot is a result of raceÂrelated tensions between Blacks and Latinos.(Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times

item.title: Inland Empire will worship in person after state gives green light

item.description: In addition to dine-in restaurants and in-person shopping, Riverside and San Bernardino counties are resuming in-person worship services.
item.content:encoded: In addition to dine-in restaurants and in-person shopping, Riverside and San Bernardino counties are resuming in-person worship services.

media:content.media:description: RIVERSIDE, CALIFORNIA - MAY 8, 2020: Residents who want public health orders rescinded attend an emergency meeting of the Riverside County Board of Supervisors at the County Administrative Center in the midst of the ongoing coronavirus pandemic on May 8, 2020 in Riverside, California. Type written notes are placed on chairs to keep people from sitting near each other. (Gina Ferazzi/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Orange County deems in-person church 'essential,' says rules too restrictive for megachurches
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: The Board of Supervisors unanimously approved a resolution supporting the resumption of in-person religious assemblies starting this weekend.
item.content:encoded: The Board of Supervisors unanimously approved a resolution supporting the resumption of in-person religious assemblies starting this weekend.

media:content.media:description: SANTA ANA-CA-APRIL 12, 2020: MaryAnn Lawson collects prayer requests from people gathering in their cars in a parking lot in Santa Ana to worship in an Easter service by Rev. Robert A. Schuller on Sunday, April 12, 2020. Schuller is reviving a practice that launched his father to worldwide acclaim- the drive-in ministry. For the past four years, the younger Schuller has been preaching primarily on social media, providing daily sermons from his "church with no walls." The COVID-19 outbreak - and the loss of in-person fellowship - led him back to his roots. "People need a place to go to worship on Easter, " he said. (Christina House / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California reopening further, but L.A. County still stymied by coronavirus numbers
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby, Sarah Parvini
item.description: Gov. Gavin Newsom announced that barbershops and hair salons would be allowed to reopen in 47 of California's 58 counties. Los Angeles isn't one of them.
item.content:encoded: Gov. Gavin Newsom announced that barbershops and hair salons would be allowed to reopen in 47 of California's 58 counties. Los Angeles isn't one of them.

media:content.media:description: CULVER CITY, MAY 6, 2020: Elaina Wilcox, owner of Color & Craft Salon is photographed inside her empty salon on Main St. in Culver City. The salon has been closed since March 19, 2020 because of the coronavirus. Wilcox , who said that her rent is $3200 a month and doesn't have an income right now, fears that she will lose her salon. (Mel Melcon/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Throngs of people, many without masks, pack Venice Beach over Memorial Day weekend
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby
item.description: Californians cooped up for months under coronavirus stay-at-home orders crowded Southern California spots, pushing social distancing limits.
item.content:encoded: Californians cooped up for months under coronavirus stay-at-home orders crowded Southern California spots, pushing social distancing limits.

media:content.media:description: People walk at the boardwalk in Venice Beach during the first day of the Memorial Day holiday weekend amid the novel Coronavirus, COVID-19, pandemic in California on May 23, 2020. - Los Angeles County officials announced May 22, 2020, that beach bike paths and some beach parking lots will reopen and curbside service at indoor malls will be permitted. The county reopened its beaches a week ago but kept beach parking lots, bike paths, piers and boardwalks closed. (Photo by Apu GOMES / AFP) (Photo by APU GOMES/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: Division scrutinized for allegedly falsifying interview cards issued the most in LAPD
item.dc:creator: Ben Poston, Leila Miller
item.description: LAPD division under scrutiny for allegedly falsifying field interview cards has played an outsized role in their production, a Times analysis found.
item.content:encoded: LAPD division under scrutiny for allegedly falsifying field interview cards has played an outsized role in their production, a Times analysis found.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CALIF. -- SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 21, 2015: Officers from the LAPD's newly expanded Metropolitan Division, stay with the driver and passenger, check them for tattoos while other officers search the vehicle in Los Angeles, Calif., on Nov. 21, 2015. (Marcus Yam / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Authorities crack down on illicit Hollywood Hills parties at short-term rentals
item.dc:creator: Richard Winton
item.description: The L.A. city attorney and LAPD are warning homeowners they can be held accountable for renters' parties during the coronavirus restrictions.
item.content:encoded: The L.A. city attorney and LAPD are warning homeowners they can be held accountable for renters' parties during the coronavirus restrictions.

media:content.media:description: Famous Hollywood sign atop Mt. Lee.

item.title: Earthquake: 3.6 quake near El Centro, Calif.
item.dc:creator: Quakebot
item.description: A magnitude-3.6 earthquake was reported Tuesday at 12:53 p.m. near El Centro, Calif.
item.content:encoded: A magnitude-3.6 earthquake was reported Tuesday at 12:53 p.m. near El Centro, Calif.

media:content.media:description: A magnitude 3.5 earthquake was reported Tuesday afternoon May 26, 2020, at 12:53 p.m. Pacific time 11 miles from El Centro, Calif.

item.title: Hair salons, barbershops can reopen now, in Stage 3 of Newsom's plan; L.A. also loosens some restrictions
item.dc:creator: Taryn Luna, Stephanie Lai
item.description: Gov. Newsom said California barbershops, hair salons, nail salons and other grooming services could reopen under Stage 3 of his reopening plan.
item.content:encoded: Gov. Newsom said California barbershops, hair salons, nail salons and other grooming services could reopen under Stage 3 of his reopening plan.

media:content.media:description: ATWATER, CA - MAY 26, 2020 - - Rosa Pedraza, wearing a protective mask against COVID-19, cuts Robert Nunez' hair at Rosa Hair Salon in Atwater, California on May 26, 2020. Pedraza has owned the business for 17 years in Atwater. California Governor Gavin Newsom says California counties that have been granted regional variances allowing more types of businesses to reopen can now permit the reopening of barbershops and hair salons, with modifications such as protective gear and face coverings. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: 3 Metro buses catch fire in Carson; one person injured
item.dc:creator: Priscella Vega
item.description: It is unclear how the three buses caught fire at a transportation hub in Carson. One person had minor injuries.
item.content:encoded: It is unclear how the three buses caught fire at a transportation hub in Carson. One person had minor injuries.

item.title: Los Angeles opens its largest coronavirus testing site at Dodger Stadium
item.dc:creator: Priscella Vega
item.description: Los Angeles opens its largest coronavirus testing site at Dodger Stadium, where up to 6,000 people a day can be tested from their cars.
item.content:encoded: Los Angeles opens its largest coronavirus testing site at Dodger Stadium, where up to 6,000 people a day can be tested from their cars.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES-CA-MAY 26, 2020: Drive-through coronavirus testing at Dodger Stadium in Elysian Park on Tuesday, May 26, 2020. (Christina House / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Eaton Canyon closed till June 1 after being overrun by visitors
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth, Luke Money
item.description: The Pasadena hiking spot was shut down Sunday after visitors, many not practicing social distancing due to coronavirus outbreak, crowded the trails.
item.content:encoded: The Pasadena hiking spot was shut down Sunday after visitors, many not practicing social distancing due to coronavirus outbreak, crowded the trails.

media:content.media:description: PASADENA, CA - MAY 24: Visitors stream into and out of Eaton Canyon Natural Area Park on Sunday, May 24, 2020 in Pasadena, CA during the Memorial Day weekend. Signs and park volunteers reminded visitors to wear their masks. (Myung J. Chun / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Myung J. Chun/Myung J. Chun/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Coronavirus 'silent spreaders' become a bigger risk as California reopens
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II
item.description: There's increasing concern that people infected with COVID-19 who show no signs of illness are playing a large role in the transmission of COVID-19.
item.content:encoded: There's increasing concern that people infected with COVID-19 who show no signs of illness are playing a large role in the transmission of COVID-19.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MAY 22: Hainan Airlines flight crew in full biohazard suit at Tom Bradley Terminal. Due to global pandemic and upcoming Memorial Day Weekend travelers are strongly advised to follow mask and social distancing recommendations at Los Angeles International Airport. Los Angeles Airport LAX on Friday, May 22, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Heat wave to bake parts of Southern California, dry out vegetation that can fuel fires
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: Triple-digit temperatures are expected in some Southern California inland areas, while the valleys will reach the 90s, according to the weather service.
item.content:encoded: Triple-digit temperatures are expected in some Southern California inland areas, while the valleys will reach the 90s, according to the weather service.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MAY 26: Smokey Bear wears a protective face mask as he warns of High Fire Danger at the Riverside Drive and Los Feliz Blvd entrance to Griffith Park in Los Angeles Tuesday, May 26, 2020 as the Southland's latest heat wave will send the mercury soaring into triple-digit territory raising the risk of heat-related illnesses. In some locations an excessive heat warning will be in effect and temperatures are forecast to be around 20 degrees higher than normal. But even where no excessive warning has been issued ... the heat will be brutal ... especially for those working or participating in outdoor activities.... Griffith Park on Tuesday, May 26, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)
